chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect pityriasis rosea?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Suspect pityriasis rosea in a person presenting with skin lesions with the following features (images are available at www.dermnetnz.org):
    • Appearance of individual lesions:
      • Multiple, discrete, pink-red ('salmon coloured') or fawn coloured.
      • Flat or slightly raised.
      • Circular or oval, and typically 0.5–1 cm in diameter.
      • Usually slightly scaly — the centre tends to clear leaving the classical appearance of peripheral 'collarette' scaling around the edge of the lesion.
      • The lesions are not vesicular and do not tend to occur on palmar or plantar skin surfaces.
    • Distribution of lesions:
      • The rash is usually symmetrical.
      • Most lesions occur on the trunk and proximal limbs, with few (usually less than 10%) distal to the mid-upper arm and mid-thigh.
      • On the trunk, lesions occur along the lines of cleavage parallel to the ribs (forming a 'Christmas tree' pattern on the upper back and V-shaped pattern on the upper chest) and are distributed transversely across the lower abdomen and lower back.
      • The face and scalp may be involved in children.
  • Pityriasis rosea typically starts with a 'herald patch' that appears before the generalized eruption, although this may not always be present.
    • The interval between the appearance of the herald patch and the more widespread rash is usually 5–15 days but can be shorter or longer.
    • The herald patch is usually larger than subsequent lesions (typically 2–5 cm in diameter, occasionally much larger), well defined, round or oval, erythematous, and slightly raised, with the same 'collarette' of scale at the margin as seen in subsequent lesions. It usually occurs on the trunk, thigh, upper arm, or neck but can appear anywhere on the body.
  • Be aware that:
    • Atypical forms of pityriasis rosea can occur and include:
      • Inverse pityriasis rosea — extremities are predominantly affected with relative sparing of the trunk.
      • Pityriasis (rosea) circinata et marginata of Vidal — few large patches that are often localized and may persist for several months.
      • Pityriasis gigantean — lesions are larger and fewer.
      • Pustular, purpuric, haemorrhagic, vesicular, papular, or urticarial lesions.
    • Itch may be present.
    • An upper respiratory tract infection may precede the rash. Systemic symptoms are usually absent during the generalized rash stage.
  • Consider whether the rash may be caused by another condition such as HIV or secondary syphilis.
    • Arrange further investigation/referral as appropriate — see the CKS topics on HIV infection and AIDS and Syphilis for more information.
  • Reconsider the diagnosis of pityriasis rosea if the generalized rash persists for longer than 12 weeks.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect pityriasis rosea are based on clinical guidance Pityriasis rosea from the Primary Care Dermatology Society [PCDS, 2018], a position statement from the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology [Chuh, 2016], a Cochrane review [Contreras‐Ruiz, 2019], expert opinion in a dermatology textbook [Stirling, 2010], and review articles [Chuh and Zawar, 2012; Chuh et al, 2015; Drago, 2016; Urbina, 2017; Rodriguez-Zuniga, 2018; Villalon-Gomez, 2018; Yüksel, 2019].

  • The recommendation on syphilis testing is based on expert opinion in clinical guidance [PCDS, 2018] and review articles [Chuh et al, 2015; Trayes, 2018; Yüksel, 2019].
  • The recommendation to consider HIV testing is pragmatic — rash associated with HIV seroconversion can present similarly to pityriasis rosea [Zawar et al, 2010].
